awd_titl_txt: Expanding Access to Cybersecurity Career Pathways for Rural Community College Students
awd_abstract_narration:
Keeping computers and information systems secure is a major challenge. Business, industry, and government need well-prepared technicians who can prevent, detect, and investigate cybersecurity breaches.  The growth of cyber-threats has created a need for many additional workers who have the necessary cybersecurity knowledge and skills. This project aims to help address this need by promoting students' movement along a cybersecurity career pathway from credit-bearing certificates to baccalaureate degrees. The work will involve three major tasks.  First, the project team will collaborate with industry professionals to define cybersecurity workforce needs.  Cybersecurity students will have opportunities to interact with industry professionals to learn what is required in real-world work environments. Second, the project will use virtual, cloud-based classroom and lab environments, with state-of-the-art videoconferencing technology, to deliver courses and laboratory experiences to students at the college's rural campuses in Belle Glade and Loxahatchee Groves. This approach will relieve students of having to travel long distances to attend classes and will mitigate the problem of finding qualified instructors for physical classes at the remote locations. Third, project activities will be designed to serve all students, targeting rural students, women, and students from groups that are underrepresented in cybersecurity. These populations offer talent that must be tapped to meet the region's and the nation's needs for maintaining a cybersecure infrastructure.

The project will generate new knowledge about cybersecurity education by testing the following hypothesis: Creating an inclusive cybersecurity community that includes student learning communities and cybersecurity professionals as mentors will enhance progress of students along a cybersecurity career pathway. Project activities include (1) creating a learning community to promote student engagement, (2) conducting specialized outreach activities designed to recruit rural students, women, and other populations into cybersecurity, and (3) improving academic instruction in cybersecurity and access to cybersecurity career pathways by delivering educational opportunities for students in rural areas. An objective of the project is to enable at least half of participating students annually to complete at least four courses toward a Network Support Technician College Credit Certificate or a Network Security College Credit Certificate. The project has the potential to increase the number and diversity of students who are interested in cybersecurity careers, who pursue a pathway toward that goal, and who enter the technician-level cybersecurity workforce in Florida.  This project is funded by the Advanced Technological Education program, which focuses on the education of technicians for the advanced-technology fields that drive the nation's economy.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Project Outcomes Report - Project CODE

Overview:

Palm Beach State College (PBSC) launched Project CODE (Computer Outreach for Diverse Education) to expand access to cybersecurity education for rural and underrepresented communities in western Palm Beach County, Florida. This initiative responded to the growing national demand for cybersecurity professionals and aimed to diversify the technology workforce by engaging underrepresented groups, including women and minorities. The project focused on three primary objectives:

  1. Raise awareness and participation in cybersecurity programs among rural populations.
  2. Foster a supportive learning environment to encourage female participation.
  3. Implement technology to provide access to cybersecurity distance instruction.

The project targeted PBSC's rural campuses in Loxahatchee Groves and Belle Glade, areas with limited access to technical education programs.

Key Outcomes:

 Project CODE achieved significant milestones in advancing its educational and societal goals:

  • Cybersecurity Labs and Pathways: Cybersecurity labs were established at PBSC's Belle Glade and Loxahatchee Groves campuses. These labs provided rural students with access to cybersecurity courses and hands-on learning opportunities. Additionally, the project developed pathways for high school students in rural areas to transition into PBSC's cybersecurity programs, aligning with high school curricula to ensure a seamless progression to higher education.
  • Empowering Female Students: Recognizing the underrepresentation of women in technology, Project CODE conducted targeted outreach, which included mentorship programs, recruitment efforts at local high schools, and informational sessions specifically aimed at female students. By the end of the project, 35% of program participants were female, indicating notable progress in addressing gender disparities in cybersecurity education.
  • Innovative Instructional Delivery: A hybrid learning platform was established, enabling students to access cybersecurity training remotely while practicing skills in simulated real-world environments. This approach was supported by in-person instruction at the newly established labs, ensuring students in rural areas received both technological and human support.

These efforts resulted in increased enrollment from rural areas in PBSC’s cybersecurity programs and higher completion rates for cybersecurity-related certificates.

Broader Impacts:

The societal impacts of Project CODE highlight its contribution to diversity, inclusion, and workforce development:

  • Expanding Access for Underrepresented Groups: Through targeted outreach, the project successfully increased awareness and participation in cybersecurity programs among Black, Hispanic, and female students in rural communities. This effort not only diversified PBSC’s student body but also set the foundation for greater representation of these groups in the technology workforce.
  • Strengthening Educational Partnerships: The project established partnerships with local high schools and businesses, creating a stronger pipeline from secondary to post-secondary education. High school counselors in these rural areas are now more aware of PBSC’s programs, leading to increased enrollment in certificate and associate degree programs.
  • Sustainability and Long-Term Impact: Project CODE secured additional funding to sustain and expand its efforts. A Department of Labor broadband grant will support further development of labs and certification opportunities, while local charitable organizations are providing tuition waivers to support students pursuing cybersecurity certifications.

Conclusion: Despite challenges such as the COVID-19 pandemic, Project CODE successfully achieved its primary goals of expanding access to cybersecurity education, increasing diversity in the student body, and establishing sustainable pathways for future growth. By focusing on underserved rural communities and underrepresented groups, Palm Beach State College has laid the groundwork for a more inclusive and diverse cybersecurity workforce. The program’s infrastructure, partnerships, and outreach initiatives will continue to benefit students and the broader community for years to come.

 


Last Modified: 12/19/2024
Modified by: Jeanne Murcia
